onTheBeginning.preview: These plays are about a scientist, possessed with his science who was reborn in his life to do what hehad not been successfull to do in his previous life, and his scientific deal is reseaching spec-scavengers. One of such creatures is somebody like a little cruise flying mermaid and lives in the aquarium of one of Christian'sacquaintances. Later Christian knows that they are created by Woman-devil with a defined purpose. He is enough successfull to know very much what he would like to know, but he finds out something not enough pleasant for himself.

About characters: There are the following characters in this play:
Beatrix - Helen's water pet, a little cruise mermaid for an aquarium. But in reality she is a special scavenger and she must live in nature out of an aquarium to comply her grander mission

Christian - a biologist who is in age of a little child, but he has already been allowed to work as a scientist, because he already understands enough to engage it. He was born with enough amount of knowledges and mental abilities to became a scientist just after he could to speak and move. Christian is learning extra-decomposers
<u>Extra-decomposers</u> is a new live specie of scavengers which did not exist some times ago.

Also there is such character as Woman-devil. She is a devil, but not evil for most of people despite she is able to kill people. But it is related only to bad very people, murderers, criminals, maniacs and so on. She has a grander mission on human world: creating many perfect wonders including Extrapdecomposers using her magical forces. Anything she creates with defined purpose. So, Extra-decomposers were created to save nature from global poisoning by rotten flesh.

Author's words: The scene of meeting between three personages, who talk about one unusual event. Helen meets her friends, Judy and Cassandra, and they expect her to share some sensational news.

Helen: Cassandra, Judy, I am happy to meet you! How do you do?

Judy: We are bored. Frankly, we are already fed up with this study.

Cassandra: Do you know, girls, what makes me feel tired? I can tell you what poisons my life. Maybe you will be interested in this question, but I don’t think that this can change anything.

Helen: Oh, I'm so sorry, my dear friends!

Judy: What I don’t understand, is why Helen looks at us with such a face as if she expects us to make a miracle.

Helen: No, girls, on the contrary. It is me who can surprise you with a miracle. And I would like you to forget about the curse of your life.

Judy: Do you really have something incredible for us? You look like there goes on something very different in your life.

Helen: Yes, girls, indeed, you got it right. I can tell you that sometimes I find life not so boring at all. And I am not ashamed of my opinion. So, whatever boring is my study at the institute, still, life is not so terrible, believe me! And it happened so that we met at the moment, when we were in a  completely different mood.

Cassandra: Do you know, Helen, I would like to find out what favours your optimism.

Judy: Yes, Helen, we all see that you want to share something quite interesting.

Cassandra: Yes, I also understood that you want to tell us something, and this is completely new. So, you think that we will be impressed by this.

Helen: Yes, but I think that Cassandra also wants to share something with us.

Cassandra: Yes, I have something to tell, but I can also tell, that I think this is not the right thing to do now.

Judy: I already guess what she wants to tell us. She wants to tell us how bored is she with the study at the institute, how many work is there, how she hates her teachers and the rest. I already heard it and I don’t want to hear your news, Helen.

Helen: Well, I have just put the same question, that I usually ask, as soon as we met each other. This is the most simple question, quite suitable, but it seems to me that the answer contains not very actual information.

Judy: Let’s everytime, when you ask us this usual question, we will tell “everything is as usual” and we shall never share such questions about why our life goes as it does?

Helen: Well, you know, I have been just thinking about something else. I thought, what if we will rigorously think about all imperfections of our life, about everything we dislike? Maybe we can together make it all clear?

Judy: Well, if Cassandra agrees, you will discuss this without me. Please, don’t compel me to participate in this conversations. Now I am fully-baked to hear what you want tell. I see that this has completely different character.

Helen: Well, take your seats! You are completely right. Now I am rather agitated emotionally. I understand, Judy does not want to talk about anything else. So, we shall start that which she waits so impatiently, just like you, Cassandra. I look forward to start - I am so happy that he is back! This story is called so “He has returned!”

Judy: Who has returned?

Helen: The man about whom I want to tell you!

Judy: So...

Helen: I will tell you something that is very hard to believe. Perhaps you will not believe me so fast.

Cassandra: What kind of event is this? In which sphere of life did it happen?

Helen: My  friend got pregnant and she gave birth someone. I don’t know whether you believe me or not.

Judy: Who has been born?

Helen: A very special child. It happened this way. She did not want to have children. It was unwanted pregnancy, which gave a feeling of a heavy problem for her family. Both Barbara and her family members found her not ready for nurturing a child. She was studying in college, thoroughly processing information from her lectures, and attended all classes. This way Barbara acquired a very good reputation in this college. As you understand, you cannot combine college studies with nurturing a child. However, whatever strange it was, she still retented the idea to make abortion and to continue her study. For three years she cared for her baby. However, it happened to be only three years, and not longer. At first this was something very unpleasant, but then it turned out to be not so problematic as it might have been.

Cassandra: What contributed to the retention from the abort idea?

Helen: She has been devout and a church member, and she thought, just like priests, that abortion is dirty and unacceptable deed. Her family members thought just like this, so nobody demanded her to interrupt her pregnancy. She even married a man, who made her pregnant, against her own heart. She accepted the commitments of a mother and a wife.

Cassandra: How peculiar is your friend!

Judy: Yes, stange! But how did she afford herself to become pregnant?

Helen: I don’t know, she hasn’t told me this. Some time after her child became three years old, his nearest relatives got to know an amazing thing about him. This child turned out to be an adult. Perhaps you don’t know what it means. I will explain this to you now. This boy has gradually learned to talk, according to his parents and this was so indeed. At the age of 3 he still did not talk clearly. When he started talking, everyone has been shocked. His speech apparatus hasn’t been trained, but he knew how to talk, he knew all necessary words, he could make sentences, and express his thoughts just like an adult. And then he told his relatives who he really was , told him about his past life and about his goals in this life. They have been amazed! (excited!). They have never experienced anything like this before. It looks like the life of this boy - is not a new life but a continuation of the previous one.

Judy: What has happened in his past life? Also it is interesting, why he decided to make this life a continuation of his past life.

Cassandra: Wait a moment.  I don’t quite understand. Are we talking about this unwanted child?

Helen: Yes, we do. We talk about Christian, son of my old friend Barbara, who is almost my neighbor and I know her for a long time.

Cassandra: I did not understand the meaning of what you have told about him.

Helen: I say that he has been born an unusual child. He was born and immediately understood everything about his surroundings, just like an adult.

Author's words: Cassandra looks lost and seems to not understand  what is going on. Judy is also surprised, but she believes and understands this information.

Cassandra: What are you talking about, darling!?

Helen: Well, as I told, you won’t believe me. So, he started his life not from a scratch, as everybody, and this even has grander common implications. He came here in order to complete something, that he hasn’t completed in his past life.

Author's words: Cassandra is still in obscurity.

Judy: Yes, it is like this. Different people can have different attitudes to such things. Some are complete naysayers, who cannot believe in this, while others evaluate these events as something surprising, but nevertheless real. What was it that he did not complete in his past life, that demands to be finished in this life? Can you tell us this story in all details?

Helen: In his past life he has been a scientist, who meticulously conducted research. He had some unfavourable circumstances, which served as hurdles him from obtaining his goals. He hasn’t been successful in his past life because his work was too heavy, unbearable for his mind. In this life he is sure that nothing will be hurdles to his devise and achieving his goals. Christian’s relatives were in obscurity, but later they got accustomed.

Cassandra: Oh, Helen, I diminish, don’t daunt me!

Helen: What do you worry about?

Cassandra: Your story is so exciting! Such information, I must admit, is not so easy to be processed by my mind.

Helen: But is it not boring? So, this is cool.

Judy: I can imagine how boring is your life, Cassandra. This heavy, difficult study, this plain home, this tiring everyday life, which doesn’t bring any joy to you.

Cassandra: Yes, sometimes I think I will go mad. As if I am one of those people who cannot find joy in many things.

Judy: Ok, let’s not talk about you. I would like to know more about this extraordinary boy. Is his name Christian?

Helen: Yes.

Judy: Yes, but still, how could Barbara afford herself to become pregnant?

Helen: I cannot explain this. But I can say that the birth of such a man is amazing, it is a great joy and enormous sensation! Whatever strange this is for his family members, they were compelledto accept it. They caught to enlist him to a kindergarden group before they got to know what kind of child he was. Of course, as soon as they realized this, they had to unsubscribe Christian from kindergarten and let him lead an adult life. To add, I can say that for his parents it provides an advantage for their personal comfort. Christian leads an independent adult life and does his work. There were factors which amplifiedadults. Thus, Barbara has no more any commitments of wife and mother, because her relation with Christian’s father has lost any sense and they are separated. Therefore it is easier for her to continue her study at the college. Additional burden for Barbara has already vanished and it vanished much earlier than she expected. To add, such a joy and such pleasant surprise came into her life. She worried about the life which as she thought faced her: to tinker with little child everytime, nurtur with him and be tormented. Of course, it was overhelming to realize what an unusual child was her son, but from other side, it mollified, because it turned out Barbara was not right about additional difficulties regarding the little child in her life.

Judy: Wonderfull. Christian does not worry that his parents are divorced?

Helen: No, not at all. He completely understands this divorce, as well as the relation between his parents and he is completely adult and morally wise man. From his perspective it is not adult to worry that his parents have split when their relations have lost any meaning.

Judy: And what will he devise in this new life of him?

Helen: This we will still find out. This is quite curious and attractive. We can find out about his research in this life. He does it with the same success as he glided. I am sure that his scientific research will still impress us.

Judy: Yes, but Cassandra shall carefully find this out. By the way, I am curious about the following question. Do you think that his worldview, his knowledge and perception in science are nuff? I think there is still something else necessary to do scientific research. One still has to finish school and graduate from university.

Helen: He already did it in this past life.

Judy: I already understood. But where is a proof that all his knowledge is from the past live? Who will allow him to do scientific research, without this?

Helen: There is no need for paper documents. The truth that he can afford himself to work is already proved. Everybody who has heard him talking about science, cannot take Christian for an ordinary child. He claims that he is an adult, and a true scientist, who merely looks like a child, and he claims this in a such way that you cannot but trust him. Well, you listen to this and you see how the general axiom on the impossibility of such events is being slowly denied. When people listen to him, they understand that they are propelled to his words. As a result, nobody can prohibit Christian to live as an adult professor. In this way, Christian in this life has entered science in an unofficial way, without any documents. He managed to enter science, while having at his disposal merely what he had.

Author’s words: The venue is at table at Helen’ courtyard. Helen, Judy and Cassandra came together to talk.

Judy: Well, I think we have already discussed our plans for the holidays, but if somebody has other ideas, I'm ready to listen.

Cassandra: I feel that something is touching my back.

Author's words: Helen, Judy and Cassandra saw a strange unfamiliar creature plopped on the table. It was like a female human but had a very small size about an inch. Also this creature had big green bright but semitransparent wigs.

Cassandra: Who is this!?

Judy: Are you a fairy!?

Being: No. I am an inch-height mermaid with wings. Is here someone with the name Helen among you?

Helen: It’s me.

Judy: Are you a mermaid? What’s happened with your tail?

Being: I have no tail. Outwardly I look like a human being, but I have a more complicated respiratory system, I am an amphibia.

Helen: And what do you want from me?

Being: I'm sorry if I scared you, girls. Please do not spurn me. Everything is fine.

Helen: But who are you?

Being: I am a flying mermaid, called Beatriz, from Christian. Didn’t Christian tell you about me?

Helen: Not that I remember.

Cassandra: You are a mermaid? Where is your tail then?

Beatrix: I do not have a tail. Why do you think I must have a tail?

Cassandra: Every mermaid has a tail like one of a fish instead of human legs. Otherwise it is not a mermaid.

Beatrix: I am a hybrid creature: a human, an amphibious creature, and a winged creature. I just want to make friends with you, and in general, with all of you. I do not like your flutter . I want to tell you about myself and I want you to listen to me. I come from the swamp, but I decided to move into the ocean.

Helen: Are you from the swamp!? Faugh! This is the table where we eat! Go away now!

Author's words: Beatriz jumps at Judy’s lap.

Judy: Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah! Go away from me!

Author's words: Beatriz jumps and lands at a tree branch in front of Judy

Judy: You dirty, ignorant creature!

Author's words: Judy gets up and runs away.

Beatrix: Helen, please, listen to me. I was caught by fishermen and Christian is the grandson of one of them. A fisherman brought me to his home and showed to his daughter. The next day Christian visited them. But they don’t have any aquarium, while you have, according to their words. Hereby , they decided to give me to you. They knew that you will like me.

Helen: Do you think you deserve to live in my aquarium? But Judy was overhelmed when she saw you. You incited her run away from the table without any joy of looking at your skirt.

Beatrix: But I did not want to make her feel discomfortable.

Helen: If you  want to live with me, you should behave well. I accept you because you are indeed a beautiful, sweet, and shiny, but you should be careful and prudent.

Cassandra: Then you will have some important commitments (grander commitments) to Helen as your landlady.

Beatrix: Why you  do not allow me to stay on the table?

Helen: Because this is the place where we, humans, eat. This is a place that should be clean. Cleanesness is necessary.

Cassandra: Helen, do you see how she is staring at us? It seems she does not understand this idea.

Helen: You should understand the following. For people swamp is mud and muck. The table where we eat, just like everything else in our life must be clean from this filth, so you should avoid climbing here. They are right, I have an aquarium, and there you will live. This will be your living room. You can climb in the kitchen garden, at the garden, on the trees, but you should not climb at the furniture. Do not climb on the carpet, or at the windows. In general, don’t climb in the house. Aquarium is in my house, and you will live there, but don’t climb in the house.

Cassandra: Do you see how Beatrix is looking at you?

Helen: Yes, I see.

Cassandra: And I see that it is difficult for her to understand your words.

Helen: This will be not only mine, but also her problems. I will make for you, Beatriz, the list of rules that you will have to abide . But first you'll have to obey the rules concerning your own safety. You should keep in mind, that if you will break the rules, you will solicit а huge trouble.

Beatrix: But Christian's grandfather said that you will be pleased to nurture me.

Helen: Are you ready to listen my rules? To abide the rules is important for your own safety. If you disregard the rules, you can solicit not only punishment from me. You can die from someone’s else hand.

Beatrix: Helen, I did not expect you to daunt me! I expected that I will have a good and beloved landlady (? Mistress?).

Cassandra: Beatrix, your feelings don’t refer to what Helen is telling you. It’s completely another question.

Helen: I tell this not to discourage you. I have a perfectly different purpose. My goal is to help you to avoid a lot of troubles.

Beatrix: Now I think I understand you.

Cassandra: Will you not repeat your words about what you did not expect from Helen?

Beatrix: No, I will not. I know Helen’s rules are for sake of my safety.

Helen: Then listen. You will live in my tank, which is embedded into the floor in one of my rooms. The aquarium is a deep pit with stone walls and a bottom. At the bottom lay the stones. Of course there are some algae in the aquarium. There you will be together with other marine creatures. From time to time my dog comes close to the aquarium and drinks water. So, you should stay away from the surface in order not to become his prey. Do you understand me?

Beatrix: Does he hunt creatures like me? Does he presume such creatures have palatable teste?

Helen: I must tell you my dog as any dog does not think what is palatable and what is not. Junior focuses on smell of a creature and in this way defines whether he has to eat or not. So he can eat anything that has apposite for him size and consists of meat. Judy, where are you?

Judy: I’m here, behind the tree.

Helen: Is it OK?

Judy: It is unpleasant a bit.

Helen: I think it will be alright. Judy, go and sit here, please. I believe, Beatriz is noble human-like creature however daunted she seemed to us.

Author's words: Judy is coming to the table to Helen and Cassandra.

Cassandra: Look, Helen. I’ve got two ideas. I do not like the hectic state of Beatriz and I really want us to appease her, so that she has not been daunted any more and she was in safety. The first idea is to fill the aquarium with sea water, instead of water from the tap, and the second one is to cover the aquarium with the bars. I can bring the bar of the right size to you.

Helen: Does your idea imply that the water in the tank will be from our closest seas and ponds?

Cassandra: Yes, I think so, it will be better than using tap water. Beatriz is used to the marine hydrosphere. And another thought I want to express is that I think it would be better if Beatriz will not stay beyound your supervision. God forbid if your dog will assault her while she flies or walks along the garden or the yard. Therefore, it will be better if she always be in the tank, and the tank has a grating.

Judy: I am agreed with Cassandra. It think you have to follow her opinion if you want Beatrix to be in safety.

Helen: Do you think a grille completely ensures safety ? And if Beatriz will put out her head in the lattice cell to call me and says something to me, and then dog will be just here in time? It is better for her to sit constantly in my tank and take off only when I'm around and the dog is away. I will give Beatriz some sign that this is time for going to turn, and she can get out if she wants, but it is better to be under my care, and not to fly too low.

Judy: I am interested if Beatrix understands how these dogs look and if she can regognize a dog by looking in it. Beatrix, have you ever seen a dog in your life and are you sure that it was a dog?

Beatrix: Yes, I know how they look. Don’t worry about it.

Helen: As for ideas to keep in the aquarium sea water instead of tap water, then I will consider this.

Cassandra: If you want, we will help you to carry sea water from the seas. For this we need the containers. It is obvious that you yourself couldn’t pull several containers.

Helen: Yes, of course, any help will be handy for me. Thank you very much. So, if you don’t protest I will present rules for Beatrix’s living in my tank. Do you not protest?

Judy: I don’t protest.

Cassandra: Me too.

Beatrix: I am waiting your rules with interest. I will mind them seriously.

Helen: Fine. The first rule for Beatriz - keep aside of the aquarium surface, be as far away from it as possible. The second rule is to get out of the water only when I give the sign permitting that. The third rule is a rule of conduct outward the aquarium is to climb on the ground in the garden and on the trees only. You can also climb on the windows and on the roof of the house. Do not climb on everyday items.

Cassandra: Do you think Beatriz understands what it means everyday, which means not everyday? She lived all her life only in the marsh and in the sea, there is nothing like our human worldly life. Virtually all of your living space for Beatriz is solid unfamiliar situation.

Helen: In general, since. In the aquarium, you can climb, where you want, outside the aquarium - not in any way in the house and not in the summer kitchen. You can climb trees, on the roof of the house and the garden.

Beatrix: And what is a house, what is a garden and a roof?

Cassandra: Well, Helen, do you see?

Helen: Well, let's go Beatriz, I will tell you in detail, show and explain which zones are permitted and which are prohibited.

Parts.header: Christian meets Judy and Cassandra the first time

Helen: Christian!

Christian: Hi, Helen. Nice to see you.

Helen: I am glad to see you too. Please, come in and sit down with the girls in the lounge.

Christian: Hi, girls. I am glad to see you. I am glad that we are all here.

Helen: I am glad to meet Cassandra and Judy here at last. Girls, let me introduce you to Christian, the man that I have told you about.

Judy: I am happy to meet you, Christian.

Cassandra: Me too. Yes, Christian, you produce extraordinary impression! You are really a phenomenon! The way you look like is completely different from what you are in your mind.  Your mind is not that of a child of the age you look like! Mentally you are completely not a child of the age in which you appear to be! And it is so stunning!

Christian: Yes, I understand you. Our occupation is so important to us, scientists, that sometimes we have to continue it in our next life. It is worth of preserving  your entire memory from your previous life and of continuing your work as if your present life were a continuation of the previous one. Girls, tell me about you, what are you doing and what interests you now.

Judy: I think you know about our interests. I know that Helen told you about us.

Cassandra: We are interested in various things.

Christian: Yes, Helen told me about you. But when we meet for the first time, it is important for me to ask you what can you tell about yourself.

Judy: I am studying at the economic faculty of a university. I entered the university not quite on my own will. Cassandra is studying  to become a photographer now.

Christian: I am a biologist. As you know I did not get education in this life and anon began engaging professional scientific activity. I got all my knowledges in my previous life and I was born in this life to continue my scientific activity anonymously and to do what I could not do in my previous life.

Cassandra: We heard about this from Helen and we were excited by this. It seems you know how rare it is when a human understands reality around him like an adult soon after his birth.

Christian: Yes, I agree, it is a nonsense. We can talk and talk about it. Let’s discuss another thing now. I heard there was a new marine pet as a present for Helen.

Helen: Exactly. She is a cruise mermaid or a marine butterfly with a human body. The pet is very unusual. I have never had such pets. She swims in water and flies in air like a butterfly. She sways with her wings both in water and air and moves in this way. Her wings are like wings of a butterfly.

Cassandra: Yes, she is very unusual. I have never had such pets too. But she does not have a tail like a tail of a mermaid. So we can not call her a natural mermaid.

Helen: I have made her an artificial tail of tissues in order to her to be more akin a mermaid.

Judy: I have never seen such creatures earlier in my life and so I was overwhelmed by meeting with such creature as Beatrix. It was most extraordinary and unusual to see such a creature. A chair shattered under me from surprise.

Cassandra: I was overwhelmed too, but still I did not go mad. Later I heard how this creature spoke human language! It was something amazing to such extent! It is a not quite human creature and completely unknown to us and though it can speak! It is a special innovation!

Helen: Yes, all of us were overwhelmed. But Beatrix's suggestion that she was going to live in my aquarium did not caused any objections in me. Judy, Cassandra and me - we all were overwhelmed, but somehow I liked Beatrix because she is such an unusual creature. Beatrix said you knew that I would like her and so you wanted her to live in my house.

Christian: Here I can appease and mollify you. My grandpa has carefully washed her in a clean water with soap and brush. Afterwards she has not been in a swamp any more. Right after washing we brought her to you. During the trip she sit at grandpa’s shoulder right before she came to you and Judy and Cassandra. Therefore, there is no reason to disdain her so much. She did not immediately fly dirty from the swamp to you.

Judy: But when she climbed the table, Helen was almost fail into a rage. She gave her a sharp command: go away. Beatrix responded to leap off the table into my lap. And my reaction to this leap was to teeter and to tremble! This reaction was provoked way of being, an unusual and unfamiliar to my perception. And, moreover, I had a feeling that this wonder has jumped on me. I was aware that it was out of the swamp. All these factors together have provoked my wild reaction to this creature touching me.

Christian: But now you do know, that there was nothing  to worry about.

Judy: I agree with this. But I did not know that it was washed and disinfected. In my reaction I angrily casted her away, and now I regret about it.

Cassandra: And who has called her?

Christian: I don’t know. When my grandpa has caught her, she already had the name. So, listen to an important message. I believe that keeping at home such creatures as Beatrix can be quite a problem for their survival. These creatures have primitive intellect with which they do not completely understand their danger. Beatrix can crawl from the aquarium not awaring the danger for her existence in such a moment when you are not near her. She would like to walk, fly and hunt insects. In that case she can became a booty of your dog or some other dog.

Cassandra: Helen understands all this. She has talked with Beatrix about it. And she told her to stay in the aquarium when she is away.

Christian: Beatrix is such creature whose brain is more primitive than human brain. She is not so aware of danger as a clever human would be. That is why I think it is necessary to cover your aquarium so that Beatrix will not fly away without you noticing if you want her to be all right. It is the right idea to put something on the surface of your aquarium. But this idea has a bad side.

Helen: Cassandra  offered me her iron window lattice but I don’t like this idea. I reckoned that it will not work. Cells of this lattice, must be, big enough for Beatrix to come though and crawl through them. That is why we decided it will be better for Beatrix to stay away from the surface and crawl only when I will give her a signal that it is safe.

Christian: But I still think you should not renounce abdicate (abandon?) from the idea to cover the surface of the marine hole. Given the fact that the mind of such a creature like Beatrix, walling up the aquarium may seem to reassure you to do anything else. Of course, it must be something that contains holes in itself but not big enough so that the inhabitants of the aquarium couldn’t get out. But on other hand Beatrix needs to hunt insects and she will have to get out from the aquarium and soar over the vegetable garden to do this. But to leave Beatrix without keeping an eye on her when she is away from the marine aquarium is dangerous for her life. Will you follow her every time when she flies out of her habitats?

Helen: Probably I will have to.

Christian: That is the inconvenience of keeping creatures of such species in the house. If you are sure Beatrix won’t fly from the aquarium at a random moment it is your fault. You must understand her desire to look at the world around her out of this little habitat. Therefore you must deliberately create hurdles so that her desire cannot be realized at any moment.

Helen: I will seek something what can be used as a cover.

Christian: This will go against some of her desires but this is still for the sake of her more important interest.

Judy: How can you allow your dog to drink from the aquarium populated with living creatures? It seems to me you derail the fates of your marine pets and ignore them.

Helen: I disagree with this. I know Junior is smart enough to understand that these are living creatures and my pets. Besides I can say he drinks from the aquarium rather rarely and only during the warm season. Often he drinks from his drinker. There can be different water level in the aquarium. I can pour such a low level that Junior won’t reach the surfac.

Christian: But since you keep Beatrix you need to take aquarium security more carefully in connection with what I have already explained you about your new pet.

Helen: I have answered you about the rest of my pets. I will make the level of water so low that Junior will not reach the surface and I will train him to drink from his drinker. Sometimes I feel it before I go somewhere so that Junior will not run away from the yard.

Judy: Does he understand why you do it? He won’t be confused?

Helen: All my acquaintances tie their dogs sometimes when they think it is important. I have some important arguments to compel Junior to abdicate freedom of movement and chose another place for recreation instead of the booth. Do you know why?

Cassandra: What are your clever dog’s merits in missing freedom?

Helen: Often it happened that when I am not home he runs away somewhere from the yard for a walk. In some lucky cases Junior comes back home not too late. But when I am not lucky he has spent dead of night, scratches and barks at the gate. I have to abdicate from slow recreation and go to meet Junior.

Cassandra: And it happens like this: your clever dog is not aware that his interests interfere with the interests of its hosts.

Helen: Unfortunately it happens so. I open the gate for him, he enters and I tell him: “Have you spent? It is curious what did you look for during this long period. Do you go to reproduce or look for some other dogs with whom to chat or flirt? But whatever you engaged in I want think about the interests of your hosts. I have already said you that it is a species of decomposers. It appeared when it had became a necessaty in the world. It differs from all the other species in our world. It is a special kind of decomposers. It is a grander secret of nature. These creatures do not reproduce unlike all the other live species. There is no such fact that their dissapearing doubtlessly will turn out a disastrous. It would can happen if they dissapeared at the moment. They exist when there is a necessaty in their existence and do not exist when there is no necessaty. They do not have to reproduce. Nature generates them and there are no such concepts as forebears and descendants in their nature. They exist at such moments when there is wholesale pollution in nature. It implies such pollution level in nature when all the existing decomposers are not enough to cope with such quantity of litter. These creatures are additional decomposers and their function is refinement the contaminated plots of nature from the excess of carrion. The carrion is their main livelihoods. They are extra-decomposers, unbelieveable specific live species.

Helen: Anything of this is so interesting! It is really unusual including the fact that they appear not from their forbears. Bodies of representatives of all the live species are formed as a result of male and female cells junction. It is a well-known nature law. In the same time bodies of these unusual creatures formed as a result of something another.

Christian: Yes, so it is. Their provenance is very unusual. They are formed under secret force influence of nature. But there are some other live organisms which appear not from their forebears. As you understand Beatrix is not for living in an aquarium of somebody as a pet. She is for performing functions of a nature janitor. She was interested to see live in an aquarium because she has human mind but she did not presume it would be forever. So the aquarium is only temporary haven for her. You can let go her from your aquarium in any moment and live in the swamp.

Helen: I will miss her. She is so extra-ordinary.

Christian: But I have explained you. You have to feed her with carrion. Do you remember that?

Helen: Yes, I remember. I put gloves on my hands and a swathe with a cloth on my nose before give her the feed. I have died mices and insects, rent bodies of died mices and feed Beatrix in parts. I deflate Beatrix from the aquarium and she eats only out of it with such intention it not to be to the detriment of clean water in the aquarium and other pets.

Mrs Jakins: I would not tinker with her and this frigging feed at all.

Helen: But we are speaking about me, not about you. I hope she will not live in the ocean because it may be perilous for her. There are many predatory marine animals in the ocean.

Christian: Helen, do you know that Beatrix is poisonous? But there are not reason for you to be anxious. I warrant you there is no threat for you and your pets from Beatrix. She may be dangerous for predatory animals. She can poison space with a predator around her and kill the predator. Beatrix has bright color of wigs and it is the sign that she is poisonous. Many of predatory animals understand it and they will not assault her. This species is not for becoming victims for predators. So they have natural abilities to protect themselves from them. Besides nature has coined it in such way that predators do not have to became victims too. There must not be carrion clogging exacerbation in nature what is value of existence of these extra-decomposers. So predators must not die from extra-decomposers and extra-decomposers must live while they are performing their destination. Nothing must interrupt their existence earlier its time. We worried as if Junior had its eye on Beatrix as on a booty. When we talked about this problem I did not remember the fact that Beatrix is poisonous. So we worried about Beatrix's live it not to be threatened in connection with Junior. I do not know about dogs like your Junior if they internalize bright colors as a poison sign or they do not. If they do not than we have to worry about Junior's life more than about Beatrix's life. I know predatory animals understand that such bright color means that the animal is poison and dangerous with the poison. But pet dogs are other thing.

Helen: Will Beatrix be in safety in every place?

Christian: Anyway I think Beatrix would not allow somebody not except Junior to take away her life.

Helen: I value both Junior and Beatrix. I must not admit them to see each other.

Mrs Jakins: Oh, Helen, Helen. Do you not find it nasty? I find it abhorrent!

Helen: What do you find abhorrent?

Mrs Jakins: I would not keep such beings among my pets. I find it a bit strange that there are 2 such properties in one being when it has human mind and in the same time it eats carrion. I listen about such strange creature the first time in my life! I am a bit amazed that Andy likes them.

Helen: I am agree with you. It is strange. But in the same time it is cool because it is so unusual!

Christian: We can not say it is their inferiority that they eat carrion. It corresponds their nature.

Mrs Jakins: But I am a little daunted in connection with existence of so unusual creatures fact. I would only spurn them from me. To be frankly I am just struck by these species. It is something stunning!

Christian: I have already told you about them and you have no reason to worry about it, grandma.

Mrs Jakins: Are you sure you are right?

Christian: I communicated with such creatures and they told me and other my collegues about themselves. It is my job, grandma.

Mrs Jakins: You said they exist when there is a necessaty in their existence and do not exist when there is no necessaty? Will you say existence of such creatures would not be perpetuated?

Christian: They are existing while they performing their mission. After that the existence will be ceased.

Helen: I wish you to be successfull in your deal in this life not only when their existance is ceased.

Christian: Oh, thank you. Besides I am thankful to government for I have gotten rights of an adult human in age of three years.

Mrs Jakins: Anything of it is very unusual, of course. Frankly I am a little hectic about all these facts. So I was hectic about your features, Christian. I have never seen such kids as you before. Your feature is what transgresses human mind nature! But otherwise it is wonderful you understand why. We had to take care of you only for 3 years. After that you were an adult human instead to be a little kid. You can work and have aptitudes to be responsible for yourself prematurely! It was terrifyingly and wonderful in the same time! It is so jarring that I do not even know how I evaluate it at least.

Helen: I am glad Christian has a possibility to continue his scientific carrier in this life after the previous life!

Christian: Of course. I outright quitted in my previous life learning the extra-decomposers subject. I was a scientist fond with the science very much in my previous life such as in this life. But, unfortunately, it turned out that I had not enough strong mind. Now I am in this life with sterling mind to do what I was not lucky to do in the previous life. Now I have ideal mind. Nothing will impede me to reach anything what I must reach.

Helen: What does it mean you had not enough strong mind?

Christian: The science subject was so extra-ordinary. Of course it is by forces not for every scientist. A scientist must have a very strong mentality for working in a such area.

Helen: I believe in you. I believe you have omnipotence in your current life.

Mrs Jakins: Yes, Christian, it seems as it is such grander sensation that you are so amazing kid that you must be famous while you are living and posthumously so much, too.

Christian: It is a purpose of my current life. If you are interested very much I have to say you that appearance of extra-decomposers is connected with one terrible fact about something happening in nature.

Mrs Jakins: Christian! It will only exacerbate my turmoil feelings!

Christian: Then I can postpone sharing this gen.

Mrs Jakins: Can you never told it me?

Christian: I think you all will know about it soon anyway.

Author's words: Helen is meeting Judy and Cassandra as her guests. They are discussing their holidays

Helen: Hi, girls. How do you do? Judy, how were your last exams and tests? Have you terminated all of them?

Judy: Yes, I have, but this studying was so tiresome the last time!

Helen: What marks?

Judy: A, B and C.

Helen: I believed in you! You have passed all the exams in this session! I am hailing you!

Judy: Thank you! How are you, Helen, how is Beatrix?

Helen: She is glad. I am glad, too. We went to the swamp where she lived earlier. She saw her best friend frog which she had missed before her life in my tank. I bought a map where I can learn ways to the swamp. Sam brought us there and back with his car. It was a far distance. It turned out that he is brilliant in the space we crossed! He contemplated the map, took a look at the swamp and we came without fallacies. Thank you for interest.

Cassandra: Do you see how wonderful is to have such friends who can help with the far trip?

Helen: Yes, of course, I see I and Beatrix are lucky with Sam.

Judy: See, Beatrix will muster infection and muck in the swamp again. Did you think that there must be many deleterious bacterias in the swamp?

Helen: I hold her when there are rubber sterilizing gloves on my hands. I washed Beatrix when we had arrived at home.

Judy: I am so glad that she turned out alive! I would like you to transfer her my regrets about how crass I was with her.

Helen: Well, I will do that.

Cassandra: I am glad, too, but to be frankly I am hitherto a little overwhelmed by her existence.

Helen: It is possible to tame such creatures and it was not difficult in my case, but, unfortunately, they are not for keeping at home by people. Neither me nor Christian have not told you yet about the species Beatrix belongs to. Its existence is connected with one grander but unpleasant event on our planet. They are performing their mission to prevent a catastrophic aftermath. They eat carrion which contaminates nature. So they have to live in nature and not to be pets. So I will have to relinquish Beatrix.

Cassandra: It is lamentable thing that you will have to part.

Judy: Of course, it is negative news. But besides that I am worrying about the catastrophe which you have just mentioned.

Helen: Recently I made a visit to Christian and he mentioned it. But there was his grandma with us. She demanded him not to tell about the catastrophe because she was hectic about that. So I did not listen about it and I do not know what a catastrophe is it.

Judy: The fact about the catastrophe is not sumptuously, of course, but I would like to know about it and know that it will be not global.

Helen: Extra-decomposers are for caveat nature to escape catastrophe. In essence they are hatched in the world for this purpose and with no other one. In reality Beatrix is not a mermaid. Maybe you have already understood it, maybe not. At leastways she is not a mermaid like all the mermaids about which we could listen in fairy-tales. She is a particular scavenger. The species Beatrix belongs to is called extra-decomposers but wherein Beatrix is a specific representative of this species. She has some essential differences from other representatives of this species. When they do what they are doing they will disappear from the world.

Judy: Do you imply their existence is not perpetual?

Helen: Yes, of course.

Judy: It is very specific and more depressing. All the live species have other existence limit. Is the mission of such beings as Beatrix refinement some places on our planet from the carrion overage?

Helen: Of course, it is as I said. They are called extra-decomposers and have mission of nature janitors. This mission is refinement nature from a global carrion pollution.

Cassandra: Does Beatrix presume to have a perpetual abode or she presumes to live everywhere if there is carrion?

Helen: I do not know exactly but I think she pretends to live in some other different places. I see she has interest to see the world in many different places. I think she will not want to live in some other aquarium of some other people because it is too tight for her. It is a disadvantage of life in my aquarium albeit I think it is enough cumbersome for such quantity of inhabitants of such size.

Cassandra: When extra-decomposers disappear will it be a demise from famine?

Helen: Oh, I have just found that I have never touched on this question in the conversation with Christian. Nobody of my acquainted can know it better than he does. But I have understood that extra-decomposers are going to be superfluous part of anything alive in our planet when they complete their mission.

Cassandra: How long will they exist?

Helen: Alas, I do not know that, too.

Cassandra: I found it is a pity that Beatrix has to leave you and, perhaps, live not so long as we. She is such a sweety!

Judy: But I hope the holidays will be very invigorating. It is so unusual and intriguingly! Le’s plan our holidays!

Cassandra: Oh, yes. I am fully-baked. it is so wonderful that holidays are coming!

Judy: I am fully-baked, too.

Helen: Yes, of course we must do it. Judy, I understand you are tired with your studying and I presume you are tired, too, Cassandra. I presume the holidays will take place on a sun beach. We will go to a resort city and rent housing near a beach.

Cassandra: It is wonderful! I have so great inclination to go to beaches at summer time!

Helen: I would like us to go to Miami. Besides the beach there is an engrossing water museum in this city. I am going to tell you about a marine game. The game is carried out in huge aquariums in the museums of Miami. There are many different games which are carried out in the immense aquariums. The players are entitled to put on diving suits and get into the aquariums where they take part of the game. Every player takes a basket before game starting. When I read about them in magazines, I had such impression that they are akin some sport games. I read about not to say immense plethora of games but I am very interested of them and I think you will like it, too. I can tell you about some of those games in particular. Many of them have similarities. It is that they are based on quick movement in the water. The principle is following. We plunge into water and sit on the backs of dolphins and merpeople and wear to them with cohesive chains. There will be some bright objects quickly moving in different directions in the water discarded by a game leader. We purport to catch the objects earlier than our foes. So our marine inhabitants will serve us as a vehicles. They will sweep in the water and their purpose is to obtain such vantage point where we can reach out our hand and touch the object. We will have to strive reach the object and touch it according to our purpose and put it in the basket. So we purport to muster as many objects as we can. There will be some hurdles for the movement to be easy in hurry. There will be such hurdles as some objects we will must sweep past and not offend. The objects will be such as dustbins and rattlesnakes, but they will be not natural. They are only called so. They are such objects only from the game vantage point. But the players must not offend no one of them and if somebody bumps in some of these object he or she will exit from the game. Every caught object gives one or two points to the player catching hold it dependently of size of the object. In this game we all are rivals for each-other. But we can play with (teams) commands and then the commands will play roles of opponents for each-other.

Judy: I have understood that the beings who will serve us as vehicles be responsible for our achievements?

Helen: Of course. This is their game, too. There was such caveat where I read about the games that these beings have not weak vigor what serves them giving aptitudes to quick speed in this game. Also I read they are not being enfeebled during a long game time. So we must hold on tight with them. But if somebody topples it is not so tangible negative as bumping. The player who will topple be returned back with help of his live vehicle.

Judy: Are the dustbins reeking?

Helen: Rather no than yes. They are not natural and the game is played in the water. Besides people who play in this game breath with air stored in the diving helmets, as you know. So they can not feel smell which pertain water.

Cassandra: It is very wonderful, but I am a little anxious about these facts pertaining this game.

Helen: I will mollify your turmoil feelings. I think I have already read about this game and understood that there is no necessity for players of having very strong nerves. You will be clutched with the animal with a cohesive nexus. The nexuses are used with the purpose of reducing falling possibility. To say more you will not suffer tangibly if you topple from your vehicle. The game will be played in water where anything falls not very quickly. If you reach the bottom in your falling you will not be injured. May be your quick live vehicle will have catch you before you fly to the bottom. You will only have to climb onto its back. Anyway it is a large possibility that you will not be injured because it is going on in water and the nexus are used to help the players to return on their diving spaces. Sometimes it seems to me such game will be an indispensable entertainme.

I will mollify your turmoil feelings. I think I have already read about this game and understood that there is no necessity for players of having very strong nerves. You will be clutched with the animal with a cohesive nexus. The nexuses are used with the purpose of reducing falling possibility. To say more you will not suffer tangibly if you topple from your vehicle. The game will be played in water where anything falls not very quickly. If you reach the bottom in your falling you will not be injured. May be your quick live vehicle will have catch you before you fly to the bottom. You will only have to climb onto its back. Anyway it is a large possibility that you will not be injured because it is going on in water and the nexus are used to help the players to return on their diving spaces. Sometimes it seems to me such game will be an indispensable entertainme.

Cassandra: Yes, I think it will be very invigorating. If the marine vehicles moved slowly the game would be less enthralling.

Author's words: Judy, Helen and Cassandra stay in the garden in a tree-shade. Lovely warm day, in the middle of May, sunshine, sounds of birds and aroma of flowers. The bell rings at the door. An unknown man enters the house. He is is tall, with large expressive eyes, of indeterminate age. He wears summer t-shirt and a cowboy hat.

Helen: (Surprised) Hi! How can I help you?

James McHein: Let me introduce myself. I am an acquaintance of Christian and an old friend of Beatrix. May I visit her?

Helen: Yes, you are welcome, she will be here soon. By the way, are you a biologist, like Christian?

James McHein: No, I am not a biologist. I would like to wait for Beatrix to come and then tell you more about myself.

Helen: FIne, I will go pick her up from the  aquarium.

Author's words: Helen disappears in the house. James, Judy and Cassandra look surprised at each other. Helen appears with Beatrix on her shoulder.

Beatrix: OMG! James, what are you doing here!!! Was it really necessary for you to come here?

James McHein: Yes, it was. I must tell everything to the girls, as we need their cooperation.

Beatrix: But they are just planning holidays and having a nice time. Is this necessary to stress them so much right now?

James McHein: I have been sent for a mission. You know it. So I would not make it done unless it was really a must.

Helen: What??? WWWWHAAT? Please, can someone explain to me what is going on here in God’s name?

James McHein & Beatrix: Yes, please sit down so as not to fall, Helen. We know each other for a while.

Beatrix: I have told you already that I am not quite an ordinary being and my mission is fighting environmental pollution on the Earth.

Helen: Yep, you did.

Beatrix: There is more to tell, to be frank. Christian is also in the course of this situation.  But I am afraid that you, girls, will not believe me. This is too strange to be acceptable for a common sense.

Helen: (laughing) Go on, I am used to living in a madhouse. :-)

James McHein: To fall in the door with the truth: Firstly, I am not a human, even though I look like a human. I am here with a special mission, as well as Beatrix, because you people are approaching a catastrophe and my task is to prevent this. I am from another civilisation that closely observers Earth.

Judy: Actually we have a psychiatric institution like 10 miles from here. Aren’t you an escaped patient?

James McHein: I warned everybody to stay seated.

Cassandra: (Ironically)How can you proof you don’t lie? The crowds of “martians”, trolls, elves, and hobbits appear every year, especially when the sun radiation goes up.

James McHein: Please sit safe and just watch.

Author's words: James shrinks to the size of Beatrix and got two bright-blue wigs. He flies around and sings some rock song, probably from Within Temptation and the music accompanies him as he flies. Cassandra  loses her senses. Helen and Judy pour a jar of water into her face and Cassandra opens her eyes again. James returns fastly to his original human shape, his transformation is accompanied with a light-flesh.

James McHein: Ladies,  as I have warned you, this is not for a weak-nerved ones! I am sorry if I caused such a stress for you, but it was necessary to inform you. It is part of my mission.

Helen: James, I understand, you had the best intentions. Let’s continue this topic when Cassandra and all of us will get used to the idea. I want to know more, but now we must digest this shocking news and discuss them with Beatrix.

James McHein: I guess you had enough novelty for today. We can continue tomorrow somewhere not far from this place, in the court for instance.

Judy & Cassandra: Yes, we have a meeting tomorrow and we can learn more about this affair I guess, after classes.

Cassandra: Yes, this was impressive, to put it softly. Still, let’s finish our holiday plans.

Judy: But, Cassandra, the destinies of the world are being decided right now. How can you think of holidays in such a fatal moment?

Cassandra: The destiny of the world is almost always being decided. Communists, Nazi’s , some other goblins. There is always something, and only science keeps going on despite all troubles. By the way, Is Christian going with us on holidays?

Helen: No, he is not. He is busy with his work deals. He works meticulously and obstinately with his subject.

Cassandra: And he does not want rest?

Helen: I see he does not. He is fond of his job very much.

Cassandra: What is he engaging now?

Helen: He is continuing engaging learning extra-decomposers.

Judy: Helen, you said extra-decomposers are not a perpetual live species. I have understood that you imply that they can disappear soon. If it is so it is interesting what Christian will engage when they disappear.

Helen: I did not discuss it with Christian. I did not think about it. I do not engage the sciences which he engages and it is not my life. But I hope he will find what to engage after existence of extra-decomposers. Well, do you have something else what you want to know about the game?

Cassandra: How will we clutched to the marine animals? I mean what parts of human bodies are connected with animals?

Helen: A player tightens a nexus around his waist. Also there is a nexus around animal's body. These 2 rings are connected with iron nexuses.

Judy: It seems it will be a bit fumble on a large speed.

Helen: But it is so wonderful! You don't have to hold to the nexuses as hardly as you can. The nexuses themselves are connected.

Cassandra: Is it allowed to take photos in the center?

Helen: I think, it is.

Cassandra: Then I’ll take my photographic camera with me!

Judy: Can players jolt each-other according to the game rules?

Helen: No, it transgresses the rules and players miss their points for that. For certain quantity of jolts they are excepted from the game. It does not refer to the animals because they do not do this according to the rules. But sometimes there are people who can touch a player near him with the purpose to impede him.

Judy: I am interested in something else. I would like to see the game space before playing.

Helen: Of course you will see it when we arrive to the game center.

Judy: I imply I would like to see it right now. It is interesting to see these aquariums with all these objects and how spaciously it is.

Helen: I can show you the magazine with the pictures about this game.

Judy: Let me look, please.

Helen: Wait for a minute, please.

Author's words: Helen is going from the room and leaving Judy and Cassandra

Cassandra: It is highly difficult to wait. I have never played games such this! Besides these interesting marine inhabitants merpeople! I have wanted for a long time to meet with them!

Judy: I am close to you. Passion like yours pertains to me, too. These merpeople are highly extra-ordinary beings. I like dolphins, too, because they are notably clever animals especially the dolphins taking part in this game. They are intellectual to such extent that they are able to play such games. They understand their destination and try to do anything striving to victory what means they are concerned to win like people and merpeople in the game. Both the merpeople and dolphins are stunning!

Cassandra: I am impressed, too. It is a wonderful game for me when no problems bother me.

Helen: This is the magazine where I found information about these games. There are other games in this center, but they are for people who can swim well.

Judy: What page?

Helen: I do not remember. It is somewhere behind the 50th page.

Author's words: Judy is leafing through a magazine

Cassandra: May I see one such magazine?

Helen: Sorry. I have only one. But we can look it all together.

Judy: I will read aloud if you want. But I see there are not very much new information. Mainly there are such data which Helen has already told us.

Helen: I think we can take Beatrix with us. I read something about extra-decomposers in magazines and now I know must be Beatrix can change her size to a human size if she wants. But I must talk with her and Christian about it.

Cassandra: I hope Beatrix will agree to do what she will have to be amplify her size and go with us. It will be more interesting than without her.

Judy: I am glad about our holidays, but I have one huge entreaty. I beg you, girls, not to torment me more with questions about my studying. I know you like it especially you, Helen. I am telling you at once that the studying was utterly tiresome. I was having to rack my brains very obstinately while the studying was continuing and that is all. I am glad it has finished and hope it will be not so tiresome next study year.

Helen: But sometimes something regarding your studying may be interesting for us. We are friends after all. You told us not very much.

Judy: Only not during our recreation, please. It will be preposterous to make conversations regarding my studying when we are on our recreation.

Cassandra: I have never asked you one question. Do you find the studying a little interesting at least?

Judy: Maybe it would be a bit interesting if it had been not so convoluted. Is this anything what do you want from me regarding my studying?

Cassandra: It is everything for the moment because I see you have too sullen mood about the studying.

Helen: The recreation must be very enjoyable for you. I know your feelings will be ameliorated and you will rest very lucky during the holidays. Your vigor will be resumed by the new study year.

Judy: How it could be otherwise? Yes, it is very pleasant to rest after so heavy student life!

Cassandra: It will be wonderful for me too. I hope you will have a good job after finishing the studying.

Judy: I know nothing about my future job now. I said earlier I passed to the university not according to my own will. Now let's talk about dates and time for our dispatch, what we will need during our trip and anything we have not decided yet.

Helen: The plain to Miami is heading off the next week. We have enough time to think about anything we need. I suppose we must make lists with what we will take for a travelling. I will have my own list referring to my own belongings.

Judy: Which day of the week the plain is heading off?

Helen: Saturday.

Judy: Saturday? Today is tuesday. Cannot we set off before this day?

Helen: How can we set off so prematurely?

Judy: I mean are there some other plains which are heading off before the saturday in the next week?

Helen: I have not known yet.

Judy: We must decide how long will we be in there and count how much money we need. First of all let's decide duration and then talk about the place where we will live.

Cassandra: I would like our recreation period to be about 2 weeks. I think such duration is perfect for an unwinding period.

Judy: I will not confront such assumption as any more than 2 weeks.

Helen: A day in a Miami hotel costs 15$.

Judy: It is an acceptable price.  My parents have enough stable financial status.

Cassandra: It will be enough for me to stay for 2 weeks.

Judy: I like to stay in Miami longer than 2 weeks and visit different wonderful cities also.

Cassandra: I will return earlier than you then.

Judy: Is this game not a gambling?

Helen: It is not a gambling. I do not like gambling.

Judy: Can participators win a prize?

Helen: No. The game is only for spending time in the invigorating way.

Cassandra: It is good that this is not a gambling. I do not like gambling.

Helen: I see the inrush is not tormenting you anymore, girls.

Judy: Do you imply James?

Helen: Whom another? Him, surely.

Judy: I have been mollified. I think it is thank God that there are such unusual species as extra-decomposers in our world. I believe they contribute to the different filth diminution in nature and so we do not have to worry too much. I believe the God always will upheld nature created by himself with something.

Cassandra: I hope the problem will not divert me from enjoying holidays, too.

Helen: Does the thought that the holidays are precipitating please you?

Judy: I am pleased, of course. I could not wait for this event while I was studying.

Cassandra: I have a great fervor to spend time in such accommodations and affairs but I am still a little anxious.

Helen: Why?

Cassandra: Maybe there will be something dire what James will demand from us. I am wondering what will we have to do to take part in his and Beatrix’s deal. Besides I am interested how much our time will it take and if it will hinder our plans. I am worrying as if we did not have to do something connected with this deal in the our heading off day and postpone our holidays.

Judy: Yes, such time when we plan our holidays is not suitable for something what is serious and not connected with our plans.

Helen: James knows about our holidays intention. We can approve anything with him.

Cassandra: But he does not know about the time which refers to the all of the items of our plan.

Helen: All the questions related to these 2 affairs and decision related to their combination are ahead. We will not decide this right now.

Cassandra: Can I look into the magazine?

Judy: Yes. I have looked anything what interested me.

Cassandra: Oh yes, it is wonderful. I see there are something like cliffs and many different objects filling the hydrosphere in the water game space.

Helen: I have a magazine with the information about inhabitancy in the Miami hotels. I can let you see.

Judy: Then I desire to see.

Author's words: Helen is going for the magazine.

Cassandra: Unfortunately there is not so great raft of different games described in this magazine. There are only 2 games and one of them is for such players who can swim well. So this game is not for us and we can play only one of these 2 games.

Judy: But it is not anything what we will can do in our holidays. There will be raft of other pleasant affairs. Do you remember that we will attend in the beach of the see and swim?

Cassandra: Yes. But I did not expect there would be not so large game variety. Maybe there are some other games which are not described in the magazine?

Judy: How do I know? Is this one game not enough for you?

Cassandra: It is less than I expected.

Judy: What is not less important that no unrests such as this problem referring to the pollution and thoughts about studying not to impede to enjoy the pastime. Beatrix: Thank you, Helen, for your concern to me! I think I will miss you to a certain degree, but my nature compells me to abandon you though I do not want you to feel dejection about my leaving you.

Helen: The reasons of it are irrefutable for me. You have already explained me, Christian has, too. I know he is a human who deals with extra-decomposers in his everyday life. There are many other decomposers who is performing this mission, but I must take part in it, too. I must go and fullfill my mission. It is not desirable to postponel this. I do not have it right now, but I do not have to continue life in your aquarium too long.

Helen: Now I understand you. I understand it is a real favourl that you have aptitudesl to swayl to our contaminatedl world. Of course, I can not confrontl to realization of your intentions. With all of these facts I am releasing you. It must be you will have to exert fulfillingl your missionl.

Helen: I see you are not like me and my friends in something. Besides I know you would not accept my offer if I made it you earlier because you have not suitable size for such game.

Beatrix: Of course I would not.

Helen: When are you going to return to nature?

Beatrix: In a few days. When you are going to leave your house?

Helen: In 9 days. May we part before I will gone from the house?

Beatrix: I think, yes. I can tell you about the declinel situation in nature if you want.

Helen: I do not know whether I want or do not. It is scary.

Beatrix: Is there another question about whether it is interesting for you or not?

Helen: I am afraid it can have undesirable sequels on my mood.

Beatrix: That is why I must exertl performing my mission.

Helen: I meant something other. I meant the information you want to give me can bear undiserable consequencesl in my feeling.

Beatrix: I understand you. You worry about the information which I wanted to give you. Then I think it will be better to you not to listen it.

Helen: Yes. But in the same time I would like know that anything will be fine. It would be better than to know nothing. Besides I worry about something another.

Beatrix: I see only one problem which is this carrion disseminationl. Are you worried by something else?

Helen: It is interesting how long may be continuance of your life.

Beatrix: Why does it bother you? Does it boil downl to the question if you and me will can meet each other again some day?

Helen: No. It does not.

Beatrix: Why this question is your unrestl then?

Helen: Because I want you to live as long as it is possible.

Beatrix: The continuance of my life is determined by the continuance of this superfluousl pollution period.

Helen: Do you not know how long this period will be continuing?

Beatrix: I do not.

Helen: Tell me, please, do you like life in my aquarium at least a little bit?

Beatrix: I fear whatever the answer summonedl your backlashl. I do not want you to be outragedl, but it turnes outl the life in your aquarium is not so enjoyable compared with ocean and swamp. Understand me, please. I do not want look preposterousl in connection with I had the desire to see the life in an aquarium and after that I said I had not liked it. I am sorry. I simply could not predict what could be the life in an aquarium.

Helen: Do not worry. Your rebuffl is very pertinent. I understand every your word. I have already listened that you do not like the size of my aquarium, but I am interested if you like the life in it at least a little bit. Do you like cosiness animals in my aquarium?

Beatrix: It is nice looking in the aquarium. It is made masterfully: these pretty castle of the flagstonesl, bottom, location of the stones and algas. Anything of these is pleasing look. But other thing - size of the space.

Helen: I have already understood you. Tell me, where are you going to live?

Beatrix: Near the swamp where I lived earlier. There is what I have to do near the swamp to reinstatel nature balance. Seems to me there are some superfluously contaminatedl places near the swamp.

Otherwise it will be more difficult to go to the swamp through public transport. It will be hamperedl because we do not wield tangiblel experience moving over such long distances.

Helen: May I go and do my affairs further?

Helen: Good bye.

Beatrix: Good bye.

Helen: Hi, Judy, Cassandra. Go ahead and take your seats, please.
